WRITING.TITLE: Why the "Kathy" story makes more sense if Adnan is innocent
WRITING.TEXT: So the story is that a girl has a friend come over later in the evening, he brings a friend with him which the girl doesn't know. At one point, this friend gets a call that seems to really upset him, make him nervous, saying things like "What am I going to do?" and "They're going to call me, what am I going to say?" and things like that. Her friend later says it was nothing, seemingly trying to downplay the supposed importance of the call. If he's guilty So, if Adnan is guilty, this call makes no sense as told. If the call is supposedly someone calling him to warn about the police looking for him (a co-conspiritor), then why would he react this way? If he's guilty, he would totally be expecting the police to contact him, being the ex-boyfriend and all. He wouldn't be surprised or aggravated about it over the phone. Plus, if he's guilty, the last thing he would probably do was talk nervously about events concerning the murder in a place where he can be overheard, right? I mean, if someone did call him to warn about the police, he's more likely to play it cool, act normal etc etc during the call, in order not to raise unnecessary suspicion. If he's innocent In a scenario where he is innocent of the crime, this call makes perfect sense. He is high, he gets a call, and he is upset, nervous, jittery about something on the phone. How many haven't overheard one side of a phone conversation where what you heard makes you think something really important or ominous is going on while it may not be that important of significant at all, really? You could probably make up a hundred different conversations that would have a totally innocent person responding and reacting the way he did. It's only after he was charged with murder that this call somehow became laden with meaning to Kathy, but it still would require Adnan to be a complete idiot for it to actually have been this way. Occam's Razor.

How do you figure? Kathy's testimony sort of hinges of her remembering him sounding very "worried" and "concerned" and that it wasn't "normal behavior for anybody". Doesn't sound like someone telling a story about someone acting cool...

Yeah? Not sure what your point here is. If he's innocent, would he be screaming at the cops? He just got news that his ex girlfriend is missing, and according to himself his first thought was that SHE was in so much trouble, not that he was (or would be). Either way, this post was about Cathy's story. Can't remember reading/hearing anything about what demeanor he had during the call with the cops.

Well, if Jay is being involved in a third party and is bullied to framing someone, the logical choice is for the guy whose car and phone he is currently in possession of. At the time, he may not have an exact timeline in mind, but all he knows is that he needs to pick up Adnan after track and make sure they drive around the rest of the evening smoking weed to make sure that Adnan wouldn't remember most of the evening. The actual time of the murder need not happen at a time where Adnan might possibly have an alibi, but when Jay sees the call logs and are asked by the detectives, he molds the story to fit the call logs as closely as possible, feeling certain that Adnan wouldn't remember or know what he did anyway.

WRITING.TITLE: A7RII users - how often do you shoot 42MP?
WRITING.TEXT: I've had this baby for a while now, and I'e started to shoot at 18MP most of the time for the sheer reason that 42MP files are freaking monsters to deal with, even on a fast computer. I do go back to raw 42 when shooting something of "importance" so to speak, but for normal day to day shooting, I usually use the lower resolutions and miss out on RAW. I really wish I could use RAW and lower resolution.

I use it a lot, and I love it. It's a bit soft wide open, which is to be expected. Most of the time I use it a 0.95 since that's why I bought it. Here are [some recent shots with it](http://jonaseklundh.se/pages/Mitakon_Speedmaster_50mmf095?lang=en) Only drawback of the lens is that it's really heavy for its size, being all-metal with huge glass in it.
I use the [Samyang 135/2](http://www.bhphotovideo.com/c/product/1110690-REG/samyang_sy135m_e_135mm_f_2_lens_for.html) on my A7RII and it's awesome, albeit it's manual focus.

Not sure there is an "advantage" so to speak. I like that it's only 16MP, I have a D800E and a Sony A/R II with 36 and 42MP respectively and while it's great to have that kind of resolution at your disposal, you rarely ever actually need it unless you're doing professional portrait photography or something like that. I rarely shoot RAW with my Df, and I have a few image profiles set up to mimic a more retro camera, and that's what it is, a nostalgic throwback to another era where photography was ore hands-on and I for one love it.
The file space isn't a problem for me either, it's just that the photos are so large that they become unwieldy to postprocess, especially on my Macbook Air 13" in Lightroom.

WRITING.TITLE: Manual lenses with Sony A7 RII
WRITING.TEXT: I have a few manual lenses that I use with my Sony A7 RII, most notably the Mitakon 50mm/f0.95 which I really like. Now, when using this lens I get no lens data at all in my EXIF. But when I use manual lenses with my Nikon, I can enter manual lens profiles, so when I mount my Nikon 28mm/f2.8 and select it as my non-CPU lens, I don't get a lens ID in the EXIF, but the correct focal length and aperture is recorded. Is there a way to handle manual lenses in the Sony A7 in the same way? EDIT: I don't mean adapted lenses from Nikon/Canon/etc, I mean native manual non-CPU lenses

WRITING.TITLE: K3 focusing screen for Nikon Df
WRITING.TEXT: Just received my K3 focusing screen from focusingscreen.com. It installed super easy using nothing but a pair of pliers. And now focusing with a manual lens is just as easy as it should be. The split screen makes it as accurate as the built-in focusing (which continues to work flawlessly as well). I.e. you still get the dot when the subject is in focus. You can even tell the Df to hide the focusing spot (overlaid rectangle on current focusing point in finder) when a manual lens is attached, which works amazingly. There are two metal frames inside the Df, and there are two rubber frames included with the focusing screen, adding the two rubber frames made the AF work flawlessly, both with non-AF and AF lenses. This, combined with true aperture ring support and turning off chimping/preview, makes the Df act and feel very much like a nostalgic piece of camera, and it's a joy to use.
I'm in Sweden, and delivery was just short of two weeks :)

WRITING.TITLE: Fixing Ghostbusters (2016)
WRITING.TEXT: Now, I've not actually seen the new movie, but when it was announced, I talked about how to make a reboot/sequel to the GB universe instead of what I saw in the trailer. Just a few thoughts: 1. Make it a sequel, not a reboot. I've heard conflicting information about whether or not this is set 30 years into the future of events that occurred or if it's just setting it up where the earlier events never happened, having not seen the film, I'm unsure. Either way, the story should be that 30 years ago, there were paranormal events in NY that is partly a myth, partly covered up, partly hearsay. Some people remember the strange things, the government tries to cover it up but since nothing else has happened in 30 years, no one is 100% sure just what happened, even though there are many eyewitness accounts of a huge stay puft marshmallow man (parade ballon exploding, according to the government etc etc). 2. Make the cast the offspring of the four ghost busters. It's a good way to throw in some diversity if that's what you really want. The daughter of Venkman is scientist working with occult stuff, the son of Ray is a hippie that loathe that story from back then and all the questions from reporters etc etc. 3. The storyline is that 30 years later, Gozer is back or something like that. Venkman's daughter is the only one that has kept up with this stuff to even begin to understand it but still needs information from her father, and there are some cameos by the original cast when she tries to hunt them down for more information. 4. When things get serious, the government is actually drafting the original cast as per some earlier contract if it should happen again, but since Venkman is a loon, Spengler can't be found etc etc, they move down to their kids saying that they need to get together and fix this, of anyone, they're the ones that supposedly would know best what to do. 5. So instead of a well knit group, they're people that may or may not have met in the past, with the common denominator that they all heard from their parents about this ghost events in the past. So (reluctantly for some) they need to quickly piece together information, archive footage, technology (which has been taken and kept by the government and some by the original cast). They are faced with technology "upgrades" made by the government that may or may not work, and a lot of pressure from this super secret govt division and they can't tell local police anything until they know more what to do with the situation. 6. Character development is that each offspring has it's own different level of distrust in what happened, the government, the technology or ghosts in general. Venkman's daughter is the main driving force, and in spite of malfunctioning tech from the govt, inexperience with pretty much everything, after a few failures to successes (think slimer hotel scene) they start to get a hang of it and starts to actually work as a good team catching ghosts. 7. As for major challenges, the first is to get everything working, testing it. Second is their first ghost hunt which turns on them badly due to malfunctioning equipment and really scaring them out of their mind. 8. Turning point is when they finally get a hold on Ray, whose son has no idea where he has been for the last decade. Finally some form of information is found that makes them being able to face the escalating threat 9. Crescendo is when Gozer appears, recognizing the ghost busters from before and instead of facing them on their term, drags them into the twilight zone/para-universe/whatever and they're totally cut off from everyone else, and it's up to them to defeat Gozer using nothing but smarts and the now working tech.
Amazing!

Your camera creates photos by recording the amount and wavelength (color) of light (photons) hitting the camera sensors photo sites (pixels). When it is darker, fewer photons hit each photo site and the resulting photo is darker. Using the ISO setting on your camera, you change the amount of signal amplification from the sensor. Amplification, however, always lowers the signal-to-noise ratio and you get noise (grain) in the resulting image.
The iris doesn't change the focal length (the depth) of the eye, only the "aperture" which let's in light. So the field of view is always the same.

It would become darker, yes, but no "ring", it would be exactly the same as if your iris did not open the pupil "enough". The lens inside the eye is behind the pupil and will focus whatever light it lets through back to your retina at the back of your eye. So even if the pupil is opened up larger, if that light is blocked by other means it will be the same as if the pupil didn't open up enough.

No, the iris only closes and opens the pupil, the ciliary muscle behind the iris is what helps you focus on things by changing the shape of the lens. If you know of anything about camera lenses, the pupil is the aperture opening and the iris is the aperture blades. The ciliary muscles is the mechanism that moves the focusing lenses inside the lens to focus the image.

WRITING.TEXT: During a nights sleep you go through different "phases" of sleep with different brain activity. There is a phase called REM (Rapid Eye Movement) sleep during which the vast majority of dreams occur. Only if you are awoken during this phase will you remember your dream since you woke from. During an eight hour sleep period, the average person has a total of two hours of REM sleep in which dreams occur, so that makes the odds of waking up from one lower.

Yeah, "ISO" has less to do with sensitivity and more to do with expected brightness. A camera with a larger sensor does not need to amplify the sensor signal as much as a camera with a smaller sensor to produce an image with the same brightness (I.e. The users selected "ISO")

The "data" that a sensor collect **is** light though. A larger sensor does collect more light. Which is why "ISO" is not about how sensitive a sensor is (like it was with film) but rather about how much the sensor signal needs to be amplified to produce an image of expected brightness. For a larger sensor, more light is collected and less amplification is needed for a brightness expected if ISO 3,200 for instance. Hence, less amplification = less noise.

Hogwash. As a painter myself, I can say that many artists cut out the parts of the work that they dislike. If you love making portraits but grids or whatever outline method you learned to use is tedious, you rationalize it in order to note get bored by what you do. It's like saying that a real artist would bind their own brushes, mount their own canvases, mix their own light umbra, instead of purchasing it prefabricated. So when I trace a portrait it's not because I can't reproduce it in some other way, it's because I've done that part so many times and it's boring. Also, using a projector/light table or using a transfer grid is not much different from a "cheating" viewpoint. One is slower and one is faster. That's all.
gt; If you're going for hyperrealism, it's a good idea to not trace. That's my only point. Which was the point I countered. :)
gt; If you're in the US ... don't drink coffee / sincerely, all of Europe.

WRITING.TITLE: Decoding individual.net and eternalseptember headers
WRITING.TEXT: I'm not trying to hack the usenet provider network (as per the rules), only decode some of the headers (using hashcat). Does anyone know what kind of encryption they use? Here is an example of the individual.net header I am trying to decode: q8cNyBZr8H6vQw1XWBg3Lw/QBrMuMlRjgDz4A0vDV6dfOCokS6 And here is the eternal-september header: U2FsdGVkX19bCgrkbEjt4gDrFKNANCce The eternal header is base64 and starts with "Salted__" so I am assuming some form of AES encryption, but I'm not sure. Any ideas are welcome.
No the ip is easily decoded, it's the X-Trace part I'm working with now.
To weed out trolls and sock puppets. No malicious intent. :)

Yeah my bad. The individual string is the x-trace one and it doesn't have ip anywhere else. The eternal one is the posting-account part which I want to decide, to see which sock puppets share the same account.

The full header doesn't help really. here is the full header for the eternal post: Injection-Info: mx02.eternal-september.org; posting-host="3a7acd6b6bbfe9e4e33e3a357762cf34"; logging-data="10878"; mail-complaints-to="abuse@eternal-september.org"; posting-account="U2FsdGVkX19bCgrkbEjt4gDrFKNANCce" It's the "posting-account" part of the header I am interested in. The reason is that I want to make sure that two posters are using the same posting account. I believe that this does not contain any personal information other than maybe the account name, or the account ID. And here is the X-Trace header from individual.net: X-Trace: individual.net q8cNyBZr8H6vQw1XWBg3Lw/QBrMuMlRjgDz4A0vDV6dfOCokS6 Which I believe could be the posting host of the user. Note that all these X-Trace headers seem to have a "/" in them, maybe signifying two parts: q8cNyBZr8H6vQw1XWBg3Lw QBrMuMlRjgDz4A0vDV6dfOCokS6 hash-identifier and hashid.py can't identify them, so I am asking here in the hopes that someone that has worked with NNTP software might have an idea what kind of encryption these strings usually have

WRITING.TITLE: Making outdoor furnitures out of pine?
WRITING.TEXT: So, I am having problem getting good access to hardwood in capacity where I live, but my local wood stores have plenty of pine. So I am wondering whether it is possible to build outdoor patio furniture out of pine and how it should be treated to keep for many years? My idea is using really thick pine boards to build a table, and I am assuming that the thicker they are, the more likely they are to bend, so I'll join them with dominoes and breadboards, but I am a bit concerned how the soft pine will fare against the weather in terms of rot, and sucking up water.

I figured as much. Cedar is extremely hard for me to get, but I can get my hands on pressure-treated pine, but when new fromm the store, it's usually quite moist, should I let it dry out for a while before starting to work with it?
Yes, I was planning not to paint it... Thanks for your suggestions

What my local store has is pine boards for construction and pressure treated pine boards for patios and such. Some have a limited selection of oak fittings and linings but nothing to actually build something out of.

Yes, I know, I would rather not paint it though. My idea was to brush it to get away most of the soft wood and keep a lot of the core wood to make it feel stronger on the surface, and then stain it. If I use pressure treated pine, I don't know if it can be stained - or rather *when* it can be stained..

WRITING.TITLE: I built a shelf for my lenses, using rear lens caps to mount them hanging from the shelves. I really like the end result
I built a shelf for my lenses, using rear lens caps to mount them hanging from the shelves. I really like the end result

WRITING.TEXT: Really not much of a hassle. I had the lenses in a drawer before, and just finding the right lens was a bit off a struggle sometimes. This way all lenses are always shown and have their place. All lens caps is in a drawer next to the shelf, so I can unscrew the lens with one hand and grab a lenscap with the other. :)

I routed a hole in the board so the lens caps are inset into it, then I used polyurethane glue which bonds super strongly with both the wood and the plastic. For the large lenses I also added two screws, but I don't think that would be necessary since the glue bond becomes stronger than both the wood and the plastic.

WRITING.TITLE: Roof build - need some advice on whether or not I'm thinking about it correctly
Roof over patio build, advice needed
WRITING.TEXT: So I'm building a roof over our patio (Swedish guy here, sorry if some terms are wrong, hope you understand what I mean). So [this is my house](http://imgur.com/VHnBn4J) more or less, it has it's back cut off here, but just to show the two facades that matter to this build. So it has a roof in a corner, and I want to build a roof over the part of the patio closest to the "camera" so to speak. And [this is my idea](http://imgur.com/1RLFuKb) where I build a corner roof where one side has zero length, which makes sense to me. The sideboard on the zero length part means that water/snow will drain down to the corner and into a spout at that point. Would you do it any differently. I'll attach (stringers?) to the house and then get either screws into the ground or cement blocks embedded. Here is a [top view](http://imgur.com/9DG2xyP) where the corner idea is more pronounced I think. Any ideas? I'll add channnel plastic or corrugated plastic on top of this. Amd I going about this incorrectly?

I see what you mean and my idea is not to attach the stringer to the fascia, but to the structural roof behind them. It's hard to explain but the shingles end and there is a vertical surface under them where the water spout is mounted. Behind this vertical surface and behind the fascia on it is the roof "stools" (as they're called in Swedish) which has a huge horizontal beam and a beam the roofing is built upon. The stringer would be attached to these (through the fascia). I hope you understand what I mean :)
I believe "rafter" (that you used) is what I am in reference too here :)
I'll put channel plastic or corrugated plastic on the roof: http://imgur.com/Trj5d7P so it will be transparent, but shield against rain

Right, someone else suggested this, but that would mean I would build it even larger and then overlap the house roof on both the long and short side, but still building a sloping corner roof? The clearance for the front stringer is right now 203cm (6'8") which to me sounds sufficient for most :)

I get that, but if the patio roof should clear the house roof, it would raise to be at about 7'10" at its lowest point, and require four more post at 50cm out from the house facade, which kind of defeats its purpose to be a roof for the outdoor dining area. Plus, it would not be anchored sideways, so it would have to have cross bracing to protect against sideway forces like wind and such, right? Also, the low point of 6'8" is only in the one corner front, where there is less traffic actually, towards the rest of the patio and the under-roof patio, there will be more clearance as well. I get your thinking and I value your feedback, I'm just trying to weight to pros and cons here :)

"v #228;l" can also be "insisting" as added to something you or someone should do: "Jag ska kl #228; p #229; mig" - "I'll get dressed" "Jag ska v #228;l kl #228; p #229; mig" - "I supposed I should get dressed" "Du ska kl #228; p #229; dig" - "Get dressed" "Du ska v #228;l kl #228; p #229; dig?" - "You're going to get dressed, right?" So depending on whether it's about your or someone else, the "v #228;l" changes meaning, where if it's about yourself, it's more of something you probably should be doing, but if it's about someone else, it's more of an added irritation, with an implied "should", as in it's expected from the person that he or she does it

WRITING.TITLE: (Spoilers extended) Teleportation and traveling without the books
WRITING.TEXT: So there are tons of comments about characters "teleporting" to locations in this and last season. With a shorter season and fewer episodes it is understandable. But another reason I thought of was that there is no "official" events that took place during the travels. I.e. GRRM writes at length about travels and what happens during the travels. So when Tyrion and Jorah travelled to Mereen, it was drawn out in the show because this journey is described in length in the books. Of course, the show journey and the book journey is very dissimilar but the show took its time because the book did. But now the show has no book to reference. If the events of TWOW will resemble the events in the show, we know that it will be with a lot more information about the journeys. As an adaptation, it's easier for the show writers to relate to the journey itself when the book has so much information about it, but when there is no such information, it's easier to just gloss over the journey rather than trying to invent something interesting that happens. The show has always been "simpler" than the books. More straight forward plot lines and characters, and without the books as a "crutch" this may lead to thing becoming too simple for a lot of book readers that are used to journeys being very time consuming.

Light meters measure light per square area, which is the same for FX and DX. The amount of total light is different though

It does and it doesn't. Exposure is also a value of illumination per square area, so the exposure for DX and FX is the same, but DX will get less *total* light. This is why smaller sensors appear grainier in low light. It's because if you have a FX camera set to ISO 400 and a DX camera set to ISO 400, the DX camera will try to match an expected "brightness" associated with "ISO 400", and in order to do this, is forced to amplify the signal *more* since it has received less *total light*. Exposure is just shutter + aperture and knows nothing about the receiving sensor size. But a smaller sensor will catch less total light, and thus need to amplify it more to end up with an equally bright image. This is why they appear to be grainier the smaller the sensors get. They really aren't, if you give the smaller sensor the same amount of total light (i.e. change the exposure), and adjust the ISO with the crop factor squared, you get equivalent pictures.

The problem is with what we call "ISO", which in the olden days meant the amount of light a film could gather per square mm, but these days, a sensor can only catch "X" amount per square mm, and then we amplify that signal and that amplification is called "ISO" steps. So, since a smaller sensor receives less total light for a given exposure, it needs to amplify the signal *more* to look as bright as the same exposure for a full format sensor. So if the FF sensor takes the shot at "ISO 400" which is just an arbitrary value tied to a perceived brightness from the old film days. But for the smaller sensor to create an equally bright image as the FF sensor, it needs to amplify the signal more. So back in the olden days, ISO was very much connected to the "grainyness" of a picture, given the fact that higher ISO film had larger silver halide crystals = more grain. But in sensors, "grain" is exchanged with "noise" and is produced by the amplification process from the sensor readout, and again, a small sensor need to amplify the signal more for the same exposure = more noise. Give the smaller sensor the same amount of *total light* (i.e. change the exposure) and then turn down the ISO by the crop factor squared, then you have an "identical" image.

WRITING.TITLE: Listened to Serial again
WRITING.TEXT: With my son (16), on a road trip. He really liked it, and his impression from the podcast is that Adnan didn't do it, but it was more entertainment to him rather than any murder mystery that he felt he could wrap his head around. After listening to the podcast again, I started to dig around the old reddit group, and found this group, which wasn't around the first time as far as I can remember. And man, the worst part of Serial has to be the "guilters" and "FAP:ers". I'm a logical kind of guy and the way each side tried to discredit the other side rather than the facts/evidence is cringey :) Anyway, I can't say I'm on the "fence" or either way. It's an interesting case, and I'm not sure I personally care whether Adnan is guilty or not. I just felt I wanted to comment on some of the things that one side makes a huge deal out of and the other side make far-fetched explanations for. **Tap tap tap** I, for one, do think the police did the tapping. Not to "coach" the witness in a conspiracy/nefarious way, just that they had worked with Jay for hours trying to get a statement and when he diverged from his own statement, they need him to get back on track. **Lividity** Since the photos of Hae's burial site hasn't been seen by many, it's hard to make any conclusive statements about them without letting your preconceived notions take over. The few drawings and clay models and whatnot we've seen seem to more or less agree that her legs were on her side, while her torso were not *completely* on the side, nor completely level straight down either. Which of course would check out given how skeletons work. What I am unsure of is the testimony made by the doctor - that talked about upper lividity, if they had seen the photos and were making a statement about whether the lividity as in contradiction or agreement of the burial position or not. **Jay** As for the timeline of the day Hae was kidnapped, I wouldn't take much of what Jay says seriously. Partly because he was/is clearly leaving out/lying about information to keep himself and/or others out of trouble, also he has given so many statements that I don't think he himself remembers what actually happened that day. So apart from knowing where the car was, any information from Jay has lost all credibility for me. **Serial, Rabia, Susan** None of these are "liars", Sarah was the narrator of a podcast that selected information for an interesting narrative, not a murder mystery with the intent to solve the case. If anything, I think Sarah makes it clear many times how she isn't convinced Adnan is innocent, and the final episode says as much - just that as far as she can determine, there wasn't enough to put Adnan in jail, regardless of whether or not he did it. Some people disagree with her, but that doesn't make her a liar. Rabia is an Adnan advocate, she said so from the very beginning. She thinks he is innocent, and there is nothing wrong with that. She has certainly been selective with the data she has released, focusing on "X" while not showing "Y". Other have found "Y" that undermines "X" and therefor Rabia is a liar. That just doesn't follow. Rabia thinks he's innocent, wants him to be innocent, and just as many guilters think he is guilty and wants him to be guilty, that means you will overlook or minimise contradicting information, happens all the time, to all of us. Susan may or may not be someone that was/is just riding on this for attention, but I've so far not seen a compelling argument that she was withholding or excluding information just for the sake of it. Being hand in hand with Rabia, she was most certainly coloured by that early on, and wants Adnan to be innocent, and her actions follow that. **Adnan** Guilters wants to make a big deal out of what Adnan has said that "proves" he is guilty, but I can't find anything on Serial that points to his guilt. Listening to the podcast alone won't show either way, really. When he gets upset he has good reason to, when he talks about himself it is clear he is doing his best not to glorify himself in any way. In fact, most of the glorification of Adnan comes from the people that knew him, not himself. But I also don't buy the entire "I can't remember much" line of reasoning. Do I think Adnan is lying/withholding? Yes, you don't get called by the police when you're seventeen and then remember anything of importance from that day. I just can't see it happening. On the other hand, like Sarah points out - if he is guilty, why on earth would he allow them to make this huge podcast about it? That really doesn't check out either. It's hard reconciling Adnan's actions for the podcast with a guilty man. As Sarah said, he has to be cocky as hell to think he'd get away with it. Then again, like the Serial producer said, if he's innocent - he has to be the unluckiest man alive. That he just so happened to borrow his car and phone to the guy that was later going to frame him for murder? Occam's razor and all, how unlucky can you get? **Cell records** With Jay's and Adnan's statements about their whereabouts on that day more or less out the window, the cell record and their location doesn't have much value to me. What cell tower was being used gives a general area, and the stories we've been told very rarely line up with those general areas, at least not in a way to be called evidence of either guilt or innocence. I don't doubt the veracity of the locations, I just don't know who to trust when it comes to claims about those locations. That means also that things like the Nisha call is irrelevant to me. Maybe Adnan called her, maybe he didn't, but it doesn't mean anything either way. **Timelines** The timelines here in the sidebar is the result of a lot of work, and it seems it's taken as gospel here. Being a web developer, I can't help but think I want this all in a database, with each claim properly related to a source, and each source properly weighed. So if there is a claim that "Adnan was in school at 2:36", I want that claim to have a source, i.e. "Testimony by Asia (link)", and that "testimony" has a fixed value of credibility (i.e. evidence trumps testimony, testimony trumps heresy etc etc), and the source person also has a credibility score. That way it would be easier to build a timeline of credible events, rather than just a miss-mash of Jay's forty different stories, someone said that he said, etc etc... **So?** Oh, you made it this far? Hey! :) So, what my point? Well, there may be none, I may just be venting a bit. I just read thread and thread here of people placing way too much significance on something, or underplaying something else. I think it's safe to say that the original subreddit has far more people that believe he is innocent, while this group has far more that believe he did it. Both places have tons of hyperbole either way, and it's sometimes hard to wade through it all to find what is real and verifiable.
Ive read all there is to read :)

gt; As a computer science student, the thing you mentioned about the timelines that you'd like to see about having a database and all these other features, and/or maybe even a nice visual to go with it, is something I have considered doing as one of my next projects. Sounds like a neat idea. Yeah, and it should be crowd-sourced, with people being able to comment on and weigh on the validity of a source and/or a claim. Just to keep it as objective as possible. gt; For example, polices files indicate that the Nisha call putting Adnan and Jay together at 3:32 p.m. did happen (as you can see in the sidebar) Yeah, I've always had problems with that post, and it's a perfect example of guilters and FAP:ers both being selective of what information they take as truth. If you want to claim that Nisha remembers "better" at this date rather than on another date, which I grant you is quite possible. Then you can't ignore "Jay's Store" and only focus on "Day or two after". Both statements are in the same quote, and one of them is incorrect. If you want to bend the language to fit "Jay's store" into your preconceived notion of guilt, you have to allow the same "bending of language" for the "day or two after", wouldn't you agree? And the "fake alibi" thing is just hilarious, that Adnan or Jay would have the forethought to create a fake alibi about a "store" job that doesn't yet exist in order to create an alibi is just funny. There seems to be no other attempts of them trying to create fake alibis during the day, so why now? Be sure that I'm not saying either way. Maybe the Nisha call was on the thirteenth, maybe it wasn't. I don't think it show either guilt or innocence either way. It shows that someone remembers something incorrectly at worst. gt; when you take into account the circumstances that make it absurd for Jay to have done it, there aren't any other reasonable possibilities. At least as far as we know. All I'm saying is that there is a LOT of credence in details by either side that to them "proves" something. But actual facts and known variables are pretty damn low. And both sides jump on small things and blow them out of proportion :/

I listened to Serial when it was released and undisclosed when it was released as well. I just relistened to Serial, but I am very familiar with the claims from Rabia and company. You will note that I just offered my thoughts on those claims, and my opinion is that those claims aren #8217;t as important and significant as they make them out to be.

gt; I don #8217;t see how you get around the fact that jay knows what happened, and adnan was with jay. Not sure why you think I want to get around that fact :) gt; Further, why do you give him credit for going on a podcast, thinking that it would be ballsy? Well, Serial did that, and I just agreed.

100% my line of thinking as well. They tapped to bring Jay back on track, not to necessarily tell him what to say. They had an outline they had worked out with Jay, then they taped the testimony and when Jay went off on one of his many many mistakes and tangents, they had to lead him back to what he had already said. I'm certain that some things were introduced incorrectly by the police as well, and Jay having to fit his story to mistaken cell towers and things like that, but it's no news that Jay made up large parts (or most parts) of his testimony, but whether that was pushed by the police or by his own reluctance to say things out right is another question. It's not a police conspiracy at least. Now does it say much about innocence or guilt, only that Jay had a hard time keeping all his stories straight.

Objective-C comes from NeXT, which is the language every Mac app has been written in since OSX. OSX has more legacy from NeXT than BSD.

The appkit and foundation kit did, now called Cocoa. Project Builder and Interface Builder was directly lifted from NeXT and used in OSX, now combined and called Xcode. The vast vast majority of GUI apps in OSX and iOS are written with tools directly evolved from NeXT.

No but using Xcode to write Obj-C does. And using the multitude of userland API #8217;s does, since the vast majority was taken directly from NeXT. It has evolved greatly since then, but we wouldn #8217;t have Cocoa, Xcode and even Swift without NeXT.

Rabia and crew are FAP:ers, are they not? They believe he is innocent, at least Rabia does. This will make you look at evidence in a specific way. **ALL** the guilters do the exact same thing. They look at Nisha's police interview and **only** see the "a day or two after" and ignore the "at Jay's store" which directly contradicts the aforementioned claim. Those two statements can't both be true, and a guilter will take one as gospel and a FAP:er will take the other as gospel. Someone objective, not trying to "solve" the case, or doesn't really care whether he is guilty or not, will see it as inconclusive. Both subreddits are filled with these selective ways to read the evidence.

gt; Accept that men, especially young men in love who have had few sexual partners, are DEVASTATED by being dumped and then seeing their ex very quickly start having sex with another guy. It's gut-wrenching. A guy murdering his ex girlfriend in such a scenario is not at all unbelievable. It's rare, but murder is rare. I have no doubt that things like this happens all the time, but it's hardly proof of guilt that it CAN happen. gt; Admit that the police did their due diligence in interviewing and investigating all obvious suspects, including Don. If my memory serves me correctly, both the podcast, and especially the podcast spin-offs, peddled the falsehood that they didn't investigate Don Serial didn't, Undisclosed did. gt; Pay close attention to the way that the police didn't immediately pounce on anyone, they interviewed and investigated suspects, finally got a subpoena for Adnan's phone records, and only then were they led to Jenn, who was interrogated by police and didn't admit to any knowledge of anything, but then lawyered-up and came back in the next day to make an official statement, which consisted of her telling them what Jay had told her about the murder Indeed, what Jay had told her. gt; Now that they had something on Jay, they press him with the info they had gotten from Jenn, and that's when he tells them where the car is at. Only from Jay were they able to find the car. True, and in all of this - this is the only thing that gives Jay any semblance of credibility. Everything else that comes out of his mouth is a jumbled mess that doesn't fit reality. gt; And then there's the most damning fact that provides a backdrop to all of this: Adnan admits that he loaned his car to Jay that day, and say what you want about he cell phone evidence, it shows that they were together all throughout the day. I know. He's either guilty of a crime no one can accurately describe, including the guy that supposedly helped him - or he's innocent and the unluckiest guy alive.

I used it for the first time yesterday, at a dance exhibition where my daughter was participating, focus was as good as on a Nikon most of the time, there was a specific number where there was a lot of red (dim) light on the scene where it was hunting hopelessly. Overall, in dim light, it may be a bit poorer than natively, but I'd say it's really good overall. And the dance routine had some really dim (i.e. ISO 12800) moments, yet it managed pretty good. Is it as good as a native lens? Hard to say, but it managed really well.

I shot some pictures from a dance routine yesterday, I haven't offloaded them from the camera yet. I'll post some when I do. Far from all were perfect and the ISO is really high due to the dim lighting, but when I shoot natively with my Nikon, far from all is good then too.

WRITING.TITLE: iptables clears itself
WRITING.TEXT: So I'm having the strangest problem. I am currently being SYN flooded, so I wrote a script to track and `DROP` (via `iptables`) the IP's that were flooding me, but it didn't help, and the problem is that iptables flushes itself some every ten seconds it seems. So I run the script, several rules are added and `iptables -L` shows them. Wait a few seconds and run `iptables -L` again and they're all gone. I've obviously checked my crontabs for root and for the system, and nothing touches `iptables`, also, crontab runs as most every minute, and this is done much more often. I'm at a loss here, really. I've also turned on SYN cookies in sysctl but that hasn't helped. I'm running Debian 7.7 (wheezy) and I have a plan to upgrade, but I need to address this problem faster than I can upgrade. Is there any log I could see when iptables is changed and by what?
Ys, it doesn't matter if I add it manually or via the script, the iptables just clears (i.e. like `iptables -F`) after a few seconds. It's so weird...
Ok, how would I go about trying to find out whether I've been compromised? I'll google some as well
It doesn't loop really, and this happens if I run the script or if I add IP's manually to iptables
Thoroughly :)
I have, it didn't help. I don't know if the Debian 7.7 kernel has support for it or not?
incron is not installed...
Hundreds of SYN\_RECV accesses from hosts with names like "[tor-exit.domain.com](https://tor-exit.domain.com)" etc, and new hosts all the time. So I'm being SYN flooded from TOR exit nodes
Oooh, never heard of. I #8217;ll look into it, thanks!

WRITING.TITLE: Updating to jessie from wheezy
WRITING.TEXT: So I updated my sources.list to this: deb http://deb.debian.org/debian/ jessie main deb http://security.debian.org/ jessie/updates main contrib deb http://deb.debian.org/debian/ jessie-updates main contrib And then ran `apt-get update`, and got these errors: W: GPG error: http://security.debian.org jessie/updates Release: The following signatures couldn't be verified because the public key is not available: NO_PUBKEY 9D6D8F6BC857C906 NO_PUBKEY AA8E81B4331F7F50 W: GPG error: http://deb.debian.org jessie Release: The following signatures couldn't be verified because the public key is not available: NO_PUBKEY 7638D0442B90D010 W: GPG error: http://deb.debian.org jessie-updates Release: The following signatures couldn't be verified because the public key is not available: NO_PUBKEY 7638D0442B90D010 W: Failed to fetch http://http.debian.net/debian/dists/wheezy-backports/main/binary-amd64/Packages 404 Not Found [IP: 151.101.84.204 80] So I don't feel confident in trying to upgrade right now. What am I doing wrong?
This did the trick, thanks!

I get tons of lines like this: `type=SYSCALL msg=audit(1565165825.250:141): arch=c000003e syscall=54 success=yes exit=0 a0=3 a1=0 a2=40 a3=1e23600 items=0 ppid=18211 pid=18212 auid=4294967295 uid=0 gid=0 euid=0 suid=0 fsuid=0 egid=0 sgid=0 fsgid=0 tty=(none) ses=4294967295 comm="iptables" exe="/sbin/xtables-multi" key="iptablesChange"` So "xtables-multi" seems to be the culprit... Never heard of it.
So xtables-multi is just what iptables links to, it's a binary for lots of different iptables functions. So the audit could just as easily just say "/sbin/iptables"... So that didn't help much

Yes, my plan is stretch really, but I don't know if I can go wheezy - gt; stretch without problems - and I already have a wheezy - gt; jessie upgrade plan to follow. So probably jessie - gt; stretch after that.
Yes, I have new hardware coming in 2-3 weeks, and I will run Buster on that one. I just need to upgrade current to see if that solves my iptables problems which remains unsolved... :/
Indeed - and I noticed now that my upgrade plan includes Jessie - gt; Stretch as well, so... :)
Yeah, that's a new ppid every time, so that's no help either, but thanks...
I probably will when I go all-in on Buster, but I'm keeping to iptables for the moment

Just to give some feedback here and a great thank you for your help. I did this and managed to backtrack an iptables call from a process called "/usr/sbin/cronologd" that seemingly reset the iptables. Now, I run cronolog for Apache, but that is in /usr/bin/cronolog - so that got me worried - what is this /usr/sbin/cronologd? Google yields exactly no results so I have to dig deeper... Hmmm :/
Well it looks like it #8217;s using protection at least.
